channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2007 The New York Times Company

item.title: Glaciers in Retreat
item.description: Studying Indian glaciers offers a snapshot of the consequences of global warming for India and raises vital questions about how the country will respond to them.
item.author: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Findings: A Survival Imperative for Space Colonization
item.description: J. Richard Gott III has issued a wake-up call: To ensure our long-term survival, we need to get a colony up and running on Mars within 46 years.
item.author: JOHN TIERNEY

item.title: In the Trenches | The Hospital Chaplain: Offering Comfort to the Sick and Blessings to Their Healers
item.description: The Rev. Margaret A. Muncie ministers to hospital patients of all faiths, as well as the hospital staff.
item.author: JAN HOFFMAN

item.title: New Depths: A Godsend for Darfur, or a Curse?
item.description: A newly discovered lake under the barren soil of northern Sudan is as likely to be a source of conflict as a solution to the bloodshed.
item.author: LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: Spending: Dipping a Toe Into Marine Biology, at a Summer Camp
item.description: About 50 camps now specialize in marine biology studies, according to the American Camp Association. That is an increase of about 25 percent since 1998.
item.author: DAVID KOEPPEL

item.title: The Basics: Just a Bike Race, You Say? Think Again
item.description: How hard is the Tour de France?
item.author: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Veteran House Democrat Guards Turf on Energy
item.description: Democrats planning a hefty increase in auto fuel economy face opposition from one of their own in John D. Dingell.
item.author: EDMUND L. ANDREWS

item.title: Cutchogue Journal: No Sailor, for Sure, but He Had Relativity Down Cold
item.description: To those who knew him from Little Peconic Bay, Albert Einstein was just a bad sailor with funny hair and a funny accent.
item.author: COREY KILGANNON

item.title: Museum Review: Touch Me Feel Me Science
item.description: In the Liberty Science Center’s new science museum, everything is urgent and personal. And under this new model, something familiar is illuminated in unexpected ways.
item.author: EDWARD ROTHSTEIN

item.title: Champion at Checkers That Cannot Lose to People
item.description: The creators of Chinook, a computer program that plays checkers, now argue that it is unbeatable by human or computer competition.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Exxon Mobil Cleanup Effort Continues on Brooklyn Spill
item.description: Exxon Mobil says it is slowly removing contamination from a 1950 oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, but some say the efforts are a bare minimum.
item.author: DALTON WALKER

item.title: Marguerite Vogt, 94, Dies; Biologist and Researcher on Polio Virus
item.description: Dr. Marguerite Vogt was a biologist who helped shed light on the polio virus at a time when it was virulent in the United States, particularly among children.
item.author: JEREMY PEARCE

item.title: Islamic Creationist and a Book Sent Round the World
item.description: An Islamic creationist is mailing a lavishly illustrated, 800-page attack on evolutionary theory to scientists around the world.
item.author: CORNELIA DEAN

item.title: A Conversation With Eric Mazur: Using the ‘Beauties of Physics’ to Conquer Science Illiteracy
item.description: Eric Mazur, a professor at Harvard, wants his students to understand concepts, not regurgitate facts.
item.author: CLAUDIA DREIFUS

item.title: Bees Dying: Is It a Crisis or a Phase?
item.description: Some experts on insect biology say that without better monitoring, there is not enough information to know if anything new or calamitous is happening to honeybees.
item.author: ANDREW C. REVKIN

item.title: The Consumer: Calorie Labels May Clarify Options, Not Actions
item.description: Demand for calorie labels on restaurant food is sweeping the country but the real question is whether diners with more information will make wiser decisions.
item.author: RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Chronic Fatigue No Longer Seen as ‘Yuppie Flu’
item.description: Decades after its discovery, chronic fatigue syndrome is finally gaining some official respect.
item.author: DAVID TULLER

item.title: Study Finds Dietary Link to Risk of Eye Disorder
item.description: Certain kinds of carbohydrates may play a role in the development of age-related macular degeneration, a new study suggests.
item.author: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Fitness: The Bicycling Paradox: Fit Doesn’t Have to Mean Thin
item.description: On the whole, cycling is a lot more forgiving of body type and age than running is.
item.author: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Q & A : Blowing in the Wind
item.description: Are some trees more susceptible or more resistant to being toppled by high winds?
item.author: C. CLAIBORNE RAY

item.title: Observatory: Near Miss by Hurricane Can Bring a Big Chill to Overheated Coral Reefs
item.description: Hurricanes can bring colder water up from the deep, which can benefit bleached coral reefs.
item.author: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Personal Health: Avoiding the Dangers Down in the Garden
item.description: Many homes and gardens play host to an increasing number of hazardous plants, and children are most often at risk.
item.author: JANE E. BRODY

item.title: Really? : The Claim: UV Contact Lenses Can Replace Sunglasses
item.description: Contact lenses with ultraviolet protection were a boon for contact wearers, but do they protect against eye diseases caused by radiation?
item.author: ANAHAD O’CONNOR

item.title: Vital Signs: Patterns: An Allergic Reaction May Be Tied to Geography
item.description: Americans who live in the South may be less susceptible to the allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis, a new study finds.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Vital Signs: Regimens: Antibiotics for Children Prone to Urinary Infections
item.description: Preventive antiobiotic treatment for urinary tract infections in children may make subsequent infections more likely to be resistant to drugs, a new study suggests.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Vital Signs: Nutrition: Another Benefit Is Seen in Buying Organic Produce
item.description: A new study finds that organically grown tomatoes have higher levels of flavonoids, which may protect against cardiovascular disease.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Vital Signs: Adolescence: Studying Compliance Checks in Tobacco Sales to Minors
item.description: Convenience stores with gas pumps are the most likely to violate laws banning the sale of tobacco to minors, a new study suggests.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY
